div.title: Naomi Loses Her Family
div.verse: Back when the judges ruled Israel, there was a famine in the land. A man from Bethlehem in Judah left with his wife and two sons to live temporarily in the country of Moab.

Hebrew names: Elimelech means "My God is King"; Naomi means "Pleasant"; Mahlon means "Sickness"; Chilion means "Wasting." The man's name was Elimelech, his wife was Naomi, and his two sons were Mahlon and Chilion—they were Ephrathites from Bethlehem in Judah. They went to Moab and settled there.
Then Elimelech, Naomi's husband, died, leaving her with just her two sons.
The sons married Moabite women—one named Orpah and the other Ruth. They lived there about ten years,
and then both Mahlon and Chilion died too. Naomi was left completely alone, without her sons or her husband.

The Hebrew פָּקַד (paqad) means "to visit" or "to attend to." When Naomi heard in Moab that Yahweh had come to help his people by providing food for them, she and her daughters-in-law prepared to return home from there.
She left the place where she had been living, with both daughters-in-law accompanying her, and they started walking back to the land of Judah.

The Hebrew חֶסֶד (hesed) means covenant loyalty or steadfast love. But Naomi said to her two daughters-in-law, "Go back home, each of you to your mother's house. May Yahweh show you the same loyalty you've shown to your dead husbands and to me.
May Yahweh help each of you find security in the home of a new husband." Then she kissed them goodbye, and they all broke down crying.
"No," they said to her, "we're going back with you to your people."
But Naomi replied, "Go back home, my daughters. Why come with me? Do you think I could have more sons who could become your husbands?

Levirate marriage: a brother-in-law marries his dead brother's widow. Go back home, my daughters. I'm too old to remarry. Even if I thought there was still hope—even if I got married tonight and then gave birth to sons—
would you wait for them to grow up? Would you stay single for them? No, my daughters. My situation is far more bitter than yours, because Yahweh has turned against me!"
They cried together again. Then Orpah kissed her mother-in-law goodbye, but Ruth held on tight to her.
"Look," said Naomi, "your sister-in-law is going back to her people and her gods. Go back with her."
But Ruth replied, "Don't pressure me to leave you or turn back from following you. Wherever you go, I'll go. Wherever you stay, I'll stay. Your people will be my people, and your God will be my God.
Hebrew oath formula invoking divine punishment for breaking a promise. Where you die, I'll die, and there I'll be buried. May Yahweh punish me severely if anything but death separates us."
When Naomi realized Ruth was absolutely determined to go with her, she stopped arguing.

Hebrew: Bethlehem means "House of Bread." So the two of them continued on until they reached Bethlehem. When they arrived, the whole town was stirred up about them. The women exclaimed, "Can this really be Naomi?"
Hebrew: Mara means "Bitter," Naomi means "Pleasant." "Don't call me Naomi," she told them. "Call me Mara, because the Almighty has made my life very bitter.
Hebrew: Shaddai means "Almighty." I left here full, but Yahweh has brought me back empty. Why call me Naomi when Yahweh has testified against me and the Almighty has brought disaster on me?"
So Naomi returned from Moab with Ruth the Moabite, her daughter-in-law. They arrived in Bethlehem just as the barley harvest was beginning.

div.title: Ruth Meets Boaz
div.verse: Hebrew: גִּבּוֹר חַיִל (gibbor chayil) means "mighty man of strength/wealth." Now Naomi had a relative on her husband's side, a prominent and wealthy man from Elimelech's clan, whose name was Boaz.

Gleaning: gathering leftover grain after harvest. Ruth the Moabite said to Naomi, "Let me go to the fields and pick up leftover grain behind anyone who shows me kindness." Naomi replied, "Go ahead, my daughter."
So she went out, entered a field, and began gleaning behind the harvesters. As it turned out, she found herself working in a field belonging to Boaz, who was from Elimelech's clan.
Just then Boaz arrived from Bethlehem and greeted the harvesters, "May Yahweh be with you!" "May Yahweh bless you!" they replied.
Boaz asked the foreman of his harvesters, "Who does that young woman belong to?"
The foreman replied, "She's the young Moabite woman who came back with Naomi from Moab.
She said, 'Please let me glean and gather among the bundles behind the harvesters.' She came and has been working steadily from morning till now, except for a short rest in the shelter."

"My daughter" was a respectful form of address. So Boaz said to Ruth, "Listen carefully, my daughter. Don't go gleaning in another field and don't leave this one. Stay here close to my female workers.
Watch which field they're harvesting and follow along after them. I've ordered the men not to bother you. And whenever you're thirsty, go get a drink from the water jars the men have filled."
Bowing face-down expressed gratitude and respect. Ruth bowed down with her face to the ground. She asked him, "Why have I found such favor in your eyes that you notice me—a foreigner?"

Boaz replied, "I've been told all about what you've done for your mother-in-law since your husband died—how you left your father and mother and your homeland to come live with people you didn't know before.

Hebrew idiom: "under wings" means seeking protection. May Yahweh repay you for what you've done. May you be richly rewarded by Yahweh, the God of Israel, under whose wings you've come to take refuge."
"May I continue to find favor in your eyes, my lord," she said. "You've comforted me and spoken kindly to your servant—though I don't even have the status of one of your female servants."

Wine vinegar was a common condiment. At mealtime Boaz said to her, "Come over here. Have some bread and dip it in the wine vinegar." When she sat down with the harvesters, he offered her roasted grain. She ate all she wanted and had some left over.
As she got up to glean, Boaz gave orders to his men: "Let her gather among the bundles themselves and don't embarrass her.
In fact, pull out some stalks from the bundles for her and leave them for her to pick up. And don't scold her!"
An ephah was about 22 liters or 5 gallons. So Ruth gleaned in the field until evening. When she threshed what she had gathered, it amounted to about an ephah of barley.
She carried it back to town, and her mother-in-law saw how much she had gathered. Ruth also brought out and gave her what she had left over after eating her fill.

Her mother-in-law asked her, "Where did you glean today? Where did you work? May whoever noticed you be blessed!" Then Ruth told her mother-in-law about the one at whose place she had been working. "The name of the man I worked with today is Boaz," she said.

Hebrew: גֹאֵל (go'el) means "kinsman-redeemer," a close relative with specific legal duties. "May he be blessed by Yahweh, who hasn't stopped showing his loyal love to the living and the dead!" Naomi added, "That man is our close relative; he's one of our kinsman-redeemers."
Ruth the Moabite said, "He even told me, 'Stay with my workers until they finish harvesting all my grain.'"
Naomi said to Ruth her daughter-in-law, "It's good, my daughter, that you go out with his female workers, so that people don't harass you in someone else's field."

Barley and wheat harvests together lasted about seven weeks. So Ruth stayed close to Boaz's female workers, gleaning until the barley and wheat harvests were finished. And she lived with her mother-in-law.

div.title: Ruth's Bold Request
div.verse: One day Naomi, Ruth's mother-in-law, said to her, "My daughter, shouldn't I try to find a secure home for you where you'll be well provided for?
Winnowing: tossing grain in the air to separate chaff. Now Boaz, with whose female workers you've been, is our relative. Tonight he'll be winnowing barley on the threshing floor.
Wash yourself, put on perfume, and dress in your best clothes. Then go down to the threshing floor, but don't let him know you're there until he's finished eating and drinking.
When he lies down, note the place where he's lying. Then go, uncover his feet, and lie down. He'll tell you what to do."
"I'll do everything you say," Ruth answered.
So she went down to the threshing floor and did everything her mother-in-law told her to do.

Men slept at threshing floors to guard grain. When Boaz had finished eating and drinking and was in good spirits, he went to lie down at the far end of the grain pile. Ruth approached quietly, uncovered his feet, and lay down.
In the middle of the night, the man was startled and turned over—and there was a woman lying at his feet!
Hebrew: "spread garment" uses the same word as "wings." "Who are you?" he asked. "I'm your servant Ruth," she said. "Spread the corner of your garment over me, since you're a kinsman-redeemer."
"May Yahweh bless you, my daughter," he replied. "This kindness is greater than what you showed earlier: You haven't run after younger men, whether rich or poor.
Hebrew: אֵשֶׁת חַיִל (eshet chayil) means "woman of strength/valor." And now, my daughter, don't be afraid. I'll do everything you ask. Everyone in town knows you're a woman of noble character.
Closer relatives had first redemption rights. Although it's true that I'm a kinsman-redeemer, there's another man who's a closer relative than I am.

Stay here tonight, and in the morning, if he wants to fulfill his duty as your kinsman-redeemer, good—let him redeem you. But if he's not willing, as surely as Yahweh lives, I will do it. Lie here until morning."
So she lay at his feet until morning but got up before anyone could recognize her. Boaz thought, "No one must know that a woman came to the threshing floor."

Six measures was about 60 pounds or 27 kilograms of barley. He also said, "Bring the shawl you're wearing and hold it out." When she did so, he poured into it six measures of barley and placed it on her. Then he went back to town.
When Ruth came to her mother-in-law, Naomi asked, "How did it go, my daughter?" Then she told her everything Boaz had done for her
and added, "He gave me these six measures of barley, saying, 'Don't go back to your mother-in-law empty-handed.'"
Then Naomi said, "Wait patiently, my daughter, until you find out how things turn out. The man won't rest until he settles the matter today."

div.title: Boaz Marries Ruth
div.verse: Town gates were places for legal matters and business. Meanwhile, Boaz went up to the town gate and sat down there. When the kinsman-redeemer he had mentioned came along, Boaz said, "Come over here, my friend, and sit down." So he went over and sat down.
Ten elders formed a legal quorum. Boaz gathered ten of the town elders and said, "Sit here," and they sat down.
Then he said to the kinsman-redeemer, "Naomi, who has come back from Moab, is selling the piece of land that belonged to our relative Elimelech.

Land redemption kept property within the family. I thought I should bring this to your attention and suggest that you buy it in the presence of these seated here and in the presence of the elders of my people. If you'll redeem it, do so. But if not, tell me, so I'll know. For no one has the right to do it except you, and I'm next in line after you." "I'll redeem it," he said.
Then Boaz said, "On the day you buy the land from Naomi, you also acquire Ruth the Moabite, the dead man's widow, to maintain the name of the dead with his property."
At this, the kinsman-redeemer said, "Then I can't redeem it, because I might endanger my own inheritance. You redeem it yourself. I can't do it."

Sandal ceremony: symbolic transfer of property rights. (Now in earlier times in Israel, to finalize the redemption and transfer of property, one person would remove his sandal and give it to the other. This was the method of legalizing transactions in Israel.)
So the kinsman-redeemer said to Boaz, "Buy it yourself," and he removed his sandal.
Then Boaz announced to the elders and all the people, "You are witnesses today that I've bought from Naomi all the property that belonged to Elimelech, Chilion, and Mahlon.

I've also acquired Ruth the Moabite, Mahlon's widow, as my wife, to maintain the name of the dead with his property, so that his name won't disappear from among his family or from his hometown. You are witnesses today!"

Rachel and Leah were Jacob's wives, mothers of Israel's twelve tribes. Then the elders and all the people at the gate said, "We are witnesses! May Yahweh make the woman coming into your home like Rachel and Leah, who together built up the family of Israel. May you become prominent in Ephrathah and famous in Bethlehem.
Through the offspring Yahweh gives you by this young woman, may your family be like that of Perez, whom Tamar bore to Judah."
So Boaz took Ruth and she became his wife. When he made love to her, Yahweh enabled her to conceive, and she gave birth to a son.
The women said to Naomi, "Praise Yahweh, who hasn't left you without a kinsman-redeemer today! May this child become famous throughout Israel!

"Seven sons" represented the ideal family size. He'll renew your life and sustain you in your old age. For your daughter-in-law, who loves you and is better to you than seven sons, has given birth to him."
Then Naomi took the child in her arms and cared for him.
Hebrew: Obed means "servant." The neighbor women said, "Naomi has a son!" And they named him Obed. He became the father of Jesse, the father of David.
This, then, is the family line of Perez: Perez was the father of Hezron,
Hezron the father of Ram, Ram the father of Amminadab,
Amminadab the father of Nahshon, Nahshon the father of Salmon,
Salmon the father of Boaz, Boaz the father of Obed,
Obed the father of Jesse, and Jesse the father of David.
